内容提要：牛顿力学诞生于300年前现代工业的萌芽期，所研究的对象基本上以重力、爆炸力或弹道力为主。工业科学发展到今天，牛顿力学作为动力学的基础也应该随着动力发展而发展，要能够对所有动力（包括人为动力）现象有一个统一完善的理论体系。如：机电动力、热动力、流体动力等，已经是人类生存环境无处不在的重要部分，但用经典的牛顿力学来完整地解释它们却存在一些问题。最根本的原因是经典力学是以常规一次性施力为研究对象，现代力学要面对的多是持续性施力的情况，而光电动因、宇宙大爆炸论的出现更需要统一的理论。论文要解决的是经典动力学与现代动力学共同的“动力微分关系”，和“变量到常量”“量变到质变”的不同关系；特别是人造动力装置往往是将动力与运动体做成一体，就容易混淆质量m与作用力F的主从关系a、功能关系Nt、表里状态V。将牛顿定律各自准确地定位于动力学系统中，从而实现了经典力学与现代动力学的统一，包括与“相对论”的通解。同时也揭示了持续动力在变量与常量的交替中，可以主动地获取更大的做功能力和更多的能量利用效率。这也解决了一些动力学应用中的一些困惑和五花八门的做法。

it is silly to claim that physicists don't understand gravity and then to demonstrate explicitly that you don't understand gravity.  The Cavendish experiment measures the proportionality constant, G, but it is NOT required to establish that the force is proportional to the product of masses nor that the force is inversely proportional to the distance between squared.  The inverse square law determines the planet orbits and the central mass determines the orbit periods (years or months).  The fact that "everyday" masses' attraction to earth is exquisitely predicted by Newton's gravitation is precisely what makes Newton's gravitation "universal."  Furthermore, the fact that a predicted force is too small to measure does NOT a priori make the prediction wrong or right.  And most definitely the existence of predictions that are too small to measure does NOT make the agreement between predictions we can measure and the measurements themselves any less valid.

For the first time, I have to say, "Booo!" I mean, confirming things with direct experiment is great, and we should keep trying to do so even when it seems wasteful, but sometimes you have to accept indirect confirmation when direct experiment is infeasible and there isn't at least a plausible mode of failure. General Relativity and Quantum Electrodynamics are both gauge theories and together have been probed to precision of better than 10 decimal places on scales from electrons to neutron stars. That's an absurdly good coverage. So we can say that gauge theory works at all scales at which we can conduct an observation. If we can agree on which degrees of freedom have local symmetries, we can construct a field theory for it that will be correct to the absolute best of our combined scientific knowledge. That leaves two possibilities. Either Poincare symmetries, which lead to General Relativity as a gauge theory, break down at microscopic scale, or we can apply General Relativity until quantum effects kick in. And we would have seen the effects of the former, because it would actually break relativistic effects in QED as well, and these are some of the best measurements we have in physics! And sure, quantum gravity is a thing, so there's certainly a scale at which all of this breaks down. But evidence for universal law of gravity being applicable and correct for something like grains of sand is absolutely overwhelming. The kind of elephant that would have to be hiding in proverbial room for this not to be the case and for us to have not found a thorn in particle physics that indicates it is absolutely unprecedented. And a lot of it, like anisotropies of space that would indicate space-time symmetries being different at microscopic scales, people have been actively looking for with zero success for a long time. Law of Universal Gravity may have started as an empirical formula that required direct experimental verification, but we've gone way past that point. And when viewed as a classical approximation to the effective field theory on the underlying quantum gravity, it has experimental backing of basically the entirety of modern physics.

One of the big problems with measuring the gravitational attraction of two small objects (your yarn and tape) is noise or interference. Newton's Law is kind of an approximation, which holds most accurately when two massive objects are near each other within the same gravitational field, because gravity is not really the attraction between two masses, but between on mass and every other mass in the universe. So, the yarn and tape will have such a minimal attraction upon each other because the Earth produces much more gravitational force than them, and they're more attracted to the mass of your hands than to each other due to the larger mass. This confound of noise is part of why we have not and probably will not measure gravity to the same precision of other forces, because the only way to get a truly precise G constant is to measure the attraction between two neutrons in an otherwise massless universe. This is why the small scale is so uncertain, that and Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle is a factor to consider at distances and masses that small. On one hand, you've got a point that there's conceptually no reason to assume that it is the same the lower we go in mass and distance, but on the other hand you've gotta ask yourself at what point you would stop looking. By inferring the same principle, that our tests must confirm the theories at all scales, we have no reason to believe that any model we have isn't local phenomena. Certainly, light must be as light is in proximity to us, where the phenomenon of light is tested, but if we do not suggest that even a single of our models should reach beyond the scope of the confines under which it has been tested, the base assumption of physics that the laws of nature are the same everywhere will break down, and what all of our models end up describing is merely local.


It would mean that, for instance, the theory of general relativity could only truly be said to describe how light and gravitational waves in the proximity of Earth behaves, and thus that we cannot infer that the sun exists, because the sole observation of it is radiation and gravity, with the usual arguments of "but it has to be there, otherwise the effects wouldn't be there" simply not applying because you have yet to prove conclusively that things in different regions of the universe and on different scales behave similarly, and that one can infer things as mentioned.

How do measurements stand up to the spacetime model of gravity? While other physical phenomena are explained by forces, which are particle interactions whose influences on acceleration are inversely proportional to the mass of the things being accelerated, the spacetime model portrays gravity as a distortion in the spacetime coordinate system. Thus a thing doesn't move toward another thing because a force is pulling on it, but instead because its future (since time is just another direction in spacetime) leans into spacial coordinates. Or, with another approach, the "closeness" and "farness" of things is distorted in four dimensions in such a way that an object's perceived curved path around an object is really just a straight line when the coordinate system is "re-normalized". Either way, what we have is that a thing just will go that way, and since we tend to agree that mass is the thing that resists changes, the "force" of gravity is something we essentially "create" to explain why a feather and a bowling ball accelerate toward the surface of the moon at the same rate. Gravity as a "force" makes the phenomenon easier to understand from our own basic experiences of forces.

The problem with the approach of perceiving things from our own experiences is that there are four (three? three and a half?) fundamental forces, but at human scale, pretty much everything we experience comes from the electromagnetic force. Ice is hard, and water is all liquidy? Electromagnetic forces. Your tongue detects saltiness? Electromagnetic forces. Your brain tells your hand to click the mouse to order more salt? Electromagnetic forces. You punch a brick wall and it hurts? Electromagnetic forces. Copper dissolving in acid? Electromagnetic forces. Aerodynamic lift? Electromagnetic forces. Radio transmission? Electromagnetic forces. Your CPU doing a billion things every second? Electromagnetic forces. An electric motor? Electromagnetic forces. Reading a floppy disk? Electromagnetic forces. Reading a CD with a laser beam? Electromagnetic forces. Reading an SD card? Electromagnetic forces. Using a radioactive isotope to monitor digestion? OK, the underlying radiation thing is not the electromagnetic force (I mean, it is a little bit), but the way we detect that radiation is entirely based on electromagnetic forces. MRI, X-ray, blood glucose, O2 saturation, hydrogen breath test? Electromagnetic forces.

Most of us don't "experience" the decay of an atom. And we don't "appreciate" the coherence of an atomic nucleus, a lump of positively charged particles and neutral particles that somehow doesn't explode into pieces instantaneously.

We intuitively understand electromagnetic forces. And with every other physical interaction we experience, we try to find a model that explains it in those same terms essentially. And I don't think it's nearly enough. That's not an original idea. That's why the fundamental forces are plural in the first place.

I will admit that I think this is perhaps one of the more... misleading videos that has been published by this channel. The suggestion is that we have a different version of gravity that works on different scales. However, Newtonian gravity is just a natural result of the Newtonian limit of General Relativity, which works well to describe the universe on every scale we measure it at (with the possible exception of dark energy/dark matter, which remains to be debated).

Instead, it is chosen to suggest that extrapolation of our theories is an entirely invalid method. But we've tested gravity down to the scale of 0.1 nm (see https://journals.aps.org/prd/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevD.97.062002 for an older example) and we do not see deviations from an inverse square law. Occam's Razor thus suggests that our understanding of gravity is accurate. The scientific method would require that you present some evidence as to why we would expect it not to work... so I would have hoped to see you cite some scientific anomaly which could explain what is WRONG with assuming extrapolation of gravity to very small scales.

Science requires a falsifiable hypothesis. When we keep pushing to smaller and smaller scales and keep getting inverse square law out, it is reasonable to expect inverse square law to hold... at least until evidence is given to the contrary. But it is not some grand ignorance.
